DOC.brief_summary: Persistent chronic inflammation is an important underlying event in multiple diseases including rheumatoid arthritis, inflammatory bowel diseases and type 2 diabetes. These disorders are characterized as inflammatory in part because of the important mediating role of pro-inflammatory cytokines in their pathogenesis. This study will investigate whether transcutaneous auricular electrical stimulation of the vagus nerve will affect and decrease the inflammatory cytokine response in healthy individuals.
DOC.brief_title: Using a Transcutaneous Electrical Auricular Stimulator to Harness the Cholinergic Anti-Inflammatory Pathway
DOC.criteria: 1. Age between 1860 years, 2. Currently healthy with no medical problems 3. Able and willing to give written informed consent and comply with the requirements of the study protocol. 1. History of any of the following: cardiac arrhythmia, coronary artery disease, autoimmune disease, chronic inflammatory disease, anemia, malignancy, depression, neurologic disease, diabetes mellitus, renal disease, malignancy, dementia, psychiatric illness including active psychosis, or any other chronic medical condition. 2. Family history of inflammatory disease 3. Treatment with an anticholinergic medication, including over the counter medications, 4. Implantable electronic devices such as pacemakers, defibrillators, hearing aids, cochlear implants or deep brain stimulators. 5. Current tobacco or nicotine user (to limit potential confounding effects of exposure to nicotine), 6. Chronic inflammatory disorders 7. Investigational drug and/or treatment during the 28 days or seven halflives of the investigational drug prior to the start of study drug dosing (Day 0), whichever is the greater length of time, 8. Any condition which, in the opinion of the investigator, would jeopardize the subject's safety following exposure to a study intervention, 9. Pregnancy or lactation (Pregnancy status & lactation will be determined via selfreport), 10. Implanted vagus nerve stimulator 11. Inability to comply with study procedures
